patterns.name: Accelerating Sea Level Rise
patterns.description: The rate of sea level rise has been increasing over time, from 2.8mm/year in 1970-1990 to 3.6mm/year in 2010-2020. Projections show this rate further accelerating through 2100.
patterns.evidence: Historical sea level rise data showing increasing rates per decade. Projections of 4.4mm/year by 2030, and 5-7 feet of total rise by 2100.

patterns.name: Increasing Storm Frequency
patterns.description: The number of major storms per year has been steadily increasing since the 1970s. This trend is projected to continue, with storm frequency reaching 6-7 storms/year by 2100.
patterns.evidence: Historical data shows average of 2 storms/year in 1970s increasing to 3.2/year in 2010s. Projections show 4.5/year by 2050 and 6-7/year by 2100.

patterns.name: Accelerating Coastal Erosion
patterns.description: The rate of coastal erosion has accelerated over the historical period and is projected to continue increasing, driven by sea level rise and increasing storm impacts.
patterns.evidence: Erosion rates increased from 1.2 feet/year in 1970s to 2.1 feet/year in 2010s. Projections reach 3.3 feet/year by 2050 and 5.5-6 feet/year by 2100.

patterns.name: Sequential Impact Chain
patterns.description: The document outlines a sequence of impacts starting with sea level rise, leading to increased storm exposure, accelerated erosion, infrastructure damage, habitat loss, and ultimately complete system transformation.
patterns.evidence: The 'Sequential Impacts' section directly lists out this chain of events.

patterns.name: Varying Timescales of Feedback
patterns.description: Different geomorphological and ecological feedbacks operate over varying timescales in response to the climate impacts. Some respond quickly while others take decades.
patterns.evidence: The 'Feedback Timelines' section outlines short-term (beach changes), medium-term (marsh drowning, ecosystem shifts) and long-term feedbacks (system restructuring).

patterns.name: Decreasing Projection Confidence over Time
patterns.description: The level of confidence in the projections decreases for longer timeframes, due to increasing uncertainty, diverging scenarios, and complex feedback interactions that emerge over time.
patterns.evidence: Confidence is rated as high for 2020-2030, medium for 2030-2050, and low for 2050-2100 projections, with justifications provided.
